instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.SMC_BATLOW: What is SMC_BATLOW? SMC_BATLOW refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Got a bit of a dog of a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in today, Fixed  pp3v42 short, Bad SMC, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> shorted capacitor.

Now it sits in S5 with no <SIGNAL>PM_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present, pp5vs5 Present, <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW</SIGNAL> present, PM BATLOW not present. again, this one is bugging me a little as i cant seem to figure it and dont want to replace the PCH just yet.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: What caused these shorts? Which cap was shorted?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Was a liquid spill board, i suspect someone has messed with it before, <CAPACITOR>C6880</CAPACITOR> and the amplifier above it were both shorted.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Did you check RTC stuff? <SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is present. i havent looked at the RTC much, <SIGNAL>PP3V42_RTC</SIGNAL> is present though.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Look at <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR> etc, 32kHz from clock chip. But yeah this board was messed with and it could also have killed the PCH. I wouldn't bother too much with it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I need this one to work, its a replacement for the return that keeps catching fire :o.

I got bored of measuring and thought that as it has been sat for 6months + and has had varius people take it apart.ect i would give the PCH a reflow.

Machine came back to life, think ill replace the PCH to be safe. Am i right in saying these arnt flip chip though so i can get away with reflowing PCH's?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Probably something else got heated and made it work again. Could be corrosion under SMC or PCH. I would not replace the PCH, the most you should do to it is reball to avoid ME issues. Maybe flux the SMC and pray this one is OK. Replace the GPU too of course or it will be back again for that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Seems to be running stable. I had previously replaced the SMC as the first was dead, Think it was probably crap under the SMC that the ultrasonic cleaner didnt resolve.
Will run extended test tomorrow and cross my fingers.
